Award.AwardTitle: Using the Sunyaev-Zel'dovich Effect to Measure AGN Feedback
Award.AbstractNarration:
This program will use the Sunyaev-Zeldovich (SZ) effect (scattering of certain kinds of light by electrons) to assess, through data analysis and simulations, the impact of quasars on heating the gas between galaxies and influencing galaxy evolution. Broader impacts of the work include training of undergraduate and graduate students. The project will also include a significant component targeted at communicating the work to the general public. At the national level, Dr. Scannapieco will continue to contribute to popular science journals such as Scientific American, and present lectures at REU programs. At the local level, he will give regular public lectures, which will be coordinated through the Mars Education Project (http://marsed.asu.edu).

The SZ effect occurs when inverse Compton scattering increases the energy of cosmic microwave background (CMB) photons passing through hot, dense gas. In this way the SZ effect acts as a calorimeter, indicating exactly how much energy was added to the intergalactic medium and when. Dr. Scannapieco will employ stacking of public archival data from the South Pole Telescope (SPT), analyzing a suite of simulations using three codes, and making targeted observations to determine the way that energy deposits from active nuclei affect galaxy evolution.

POR.DRECONTENT:
In the heart of each galaxy lies a black hole, millions of times more massive than the Sun. While most of these objects are quiescent, their births were marked by fantastic explosions of light and energy, which had a profound effect on the formation of subsequent galaxies. Our program has adopted an innovative new approach to constraining such feedback, by measuring its signature with the Sunyaev-Zeldovich (SZ) effect, which occurs when inverse Compton scattering increases the energy of cosmic microwave background (CMB) photons passing through hot, dense gas.

The intellectual merit of this project lies in our group’s work with data from two microwave background telescopes, the South Pole Telescope (SPT) and the Atacama Cosmology Telescope (ACT), to measure this effect around isolated elliptical galaxies at redshifts between 0.5 to 1.5. By comparing this data to the results of large numerical cosmological simulations, we have been able to derive new constraints on black hole feedback, which show that the energy in such events may be less than assumed in most current models.

The broader impact of this project includes the training of an excellent graduate student, who has now gone on to a competitive postdoctoral position in the field. At the local level, our group has given regular public lectures both to astronomy clubs, and at large campus-based events such as the yearly Earth and Space Exploration Day and Night of the Open Door. In addition, we have presented our results in popular science articles, such as researchfeatures.com/2017/11/02/supermassive-black-hole-feedback, which aim to bring the excitement of astrophysics to the widest audience possible.
